elements.content: The assembling of [Mn(5-MeOsalen)(H2O)]+ and [(Tp)Fe(CN)3]- affords the one-dimensional zigzag chain [(Tp)Fe(CN)3Mn(5-MeOsalen)·2CH3OH] n [1; Tp- = hydrotris(pyrazolyl)borate and 5-MeOsalen2- = N,N‘-ethylenebis(5-methoxysalicylideneiminate)]. The corroborated experimental and ab initio data indicate ferromagnetic Fe(III)−Mn(III) couplings and D < 0 anisotropy on Mn(III). The field-induced metamagnetic behavior is due to interchain effects.
elements.clean_text: The assembling of [Mn(5-MeOsalen)(H2O)]+ and [(Tp)Fe(CN)3]- affords the one-dimensional zigzag chain [(Tp)Fe(CN)3Mn(5-MeOsalen)⋅2CH3OH] n  [1; Tp- = hydrotris(pyrazolyl)borate and 5-MeOsalen2- = N,N‘-ethylenebis(5-methoxysalicylideneiminate)]. The corroborated experimental and ab initio data indicate ferromagnetic Fe(III)-Mn(III) couplings and D < 0 anisotropy on Mn(III). The field-induced metamagnetic behavior is due to interchain effects.

elements.content: The assembling of [Mn(5-MeOsalen)(H2O)]+ and [(Tp)Fe(CN)3]- affords the one-dimensional zigzag chain [(Tp)Fe(CN)3Mn(5-MeOsalen)·2CH3OH] n [1; Tp- = hydrotris(pyrazolyl)borate and 5-MeOsalen2- = N,N‘-ethylenebis(5-methoxysalicylideneiminate)]. The corroborated experimental and ab initio data indicate ferromagnetic Fe(III)-Mn(III) couplings and D < 0 anisotropy on Mn(III). The field-induced metamagnetic behavior is due to interchain effects.

elements.content: The structural variety, the outlined synthetic strategies, and the challenging properties, such as high-T C magnetism, photomagnetism, and pressure tuning of magnetization, promote the cyanide-bridged complexes as top candidates for the design of new materials. Beyond the potential technical applications, the cyanide-bridged-based single-molecule magnets4 and single-chain magnets (SCMs)5 are interesting for the structural rationalization of spin and anisotropy effects. A key factor is the negative D axial term in the zero-field-splitting (ZFS) Hamiltonian. The previous obtaining of a SCM7a based on the pronounced magnetic anisotropy of salicylideneiminate (salen)-type Mn(III) complexes7b and the ferromagnetic Fe(III)−CN−Mn(III) coupling7c prompted us for the design and investigation of similar extended systems. The presented compound, [(Tp)FeIII(CN)3MnIII(5-MeOsalen)·2CH3OH] n (1), has negative D and positive J parameters. Even not having SCM features offers an interesting magnetostructural case.
elements.clean_text: The structural variety, the outlined synthetic strategies, and the challenging properties, such as high-T C magnetism, photomagnetism, and pressure tuning of magnetization, promote the cyanide-bridged complexes as top candidates for the design of new materials. Beyond the potential technical applications, the cyanide-bridged-based single-molecule magnets4 and single-chain magnets (SCMs)5 are interesting for the structural rationalization of spin and anisotropy effects. A key factor is the negative D axial term in the zero-field-splitting (ZFS) Hamiltonian. The previous obtaining of a SCM7a based on the pronounced magnetic anisotropy of salicylideneiminate (salen)-type Mn(III) complexes7b and the ferromagnetic Fe(III)-CN-Mn(III) coupling7c prompted us for the design and investigation of similar extended systems. The presented compound, [(Tp)FeIII(CN)3MnIII(5-MeOsalen)⋅2CH3OH] n  (1), has negative D and positive J parameters. Even not having SCM features offers an interesting magnetostructural case.

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained as dark-brown crystals by the reaction of (Bu4N)[(Tp)Fe(CN)3] (Bu4N+ = tetrabutylammonium) and [Mn(5-MeOsalen)(H2O)](PF6) in a 1:1 molar ratio in methanol. Crystallography data reveal the one-dimensional (1D) neutral polymer [(Tp)FeIII(CN)3MnIII(5- MeOsalen)] n , with free solvate methanol into the crystal spaces (Figures and S1 in the Supporting Information). The zigzag pattern is determined by the cis topology of bridges emerging from [TpFe(CN)3]-. The Mn ion is six-coordinated in an elongated octahedral geometry (formally, a Jahn−Teller distortion). The equatorial plane is occupied by N2O2 donor atoms of 5-MeOsalen [Mn−N(1) = 1.986(2) Å, Mn−N(2) = 1.980(2) Å, Mn−O(1) = 1.873(2) Å, and Mn−O(2) = 1.863(2) Å]. The chain shows two alternating types of Fe−C⋮N−Mn bridges, labeled here a and b, closely similar in bond lengths, e.g., (Mn−N)a = 2.364(2) Å and (Mn−N)b = 2.320(2) Å, but having different bond and dihedral angles, like (C⋮N−Mn)a = 161.7(2)° vs (C⋮N−Mn)b = 151.1(2)° and (Fe−C⋮N−Mn)a = 23.7° vs (Fe−C⋮N−Mn)b = 158.2°. Such geometry factors determine quantitative differentiation in the exchange parameters. The Fe−C bond lengths [1.920(3)−1.933(3) Å] are in the range known for other low-spin Fe(III) complexes. The Fe−C⋮N angles for both terminal [174.5(3)°] and bridging [174.4(3) and 175.7(3)°] cyanide groups depart slightly from linearity.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was obtained as dark-brown crystals by the reaction of (Bu4N)[(Tp)Fe(CN)3] (Bu4N+ = tetrabutylammonium) and [Mn(5-MeOsalen)(H2O)](PF6) in a 1:1 molar ratio in methanol. Crystallography data reveal the one-dimensional (1D) neutral polymer [(Tp)FeIII(CN)3MnIII(5- MeOsalen)] n , with free solvate methanol into the crystal spaces (Figures  and S1 in the Supporting Information). The zigzag pattern is determined by the cis topology of bridges emerging from [TpFe(CN)3]-. The Mn ion is six-coordinated in an elongated octahedral geometry (formally, a Jahn-Teller distortion). The equatorial plane is occupied by N2O2 donor atoms of 5-MeOsalen [Mn-N(1) = 1.986(2) Å, Mn-N(2) = 1.980(2) Å, Mn-O(1) = 1.873(2) Å, and Mn-O(2) = 1.863(2) Å]. The chain shows two alternating types of Fe-C⋮N-Mn bridges, labeled here a and b, closely similar in bond lengths, e.g., (Mn-N)a = 2.364(2) Å and (Mn-N)b = 2.320(2) Å, but having different bond and dihedral angles, like (C⋮N-Mn)a = 161.7(2)° vs (C⋮N-Mn)b = 151.1(2)° and (Fe-C⋮N-Mn)a = 23.7° vs (Fe-C⋮N-Mn)b = 158.2°. Such geometry factors determine quantitative differentiation in the exchange parameters. The Fe-C bond lengths [1.920(3)-1.933(3) Å] are in the range known for other low-spin Fe(III) complexes. The Fe-C⋮N angles for both terminal [174.5(3)°] and bridging [174.4(3) and 175.7(3)°] cyanide groups depart slightly from linearity.

elements.content: Structure of the 1D chain for1 with magnetic exchanges as indicated. H atoms and methanol molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of the 1D chain for1 with magnetic exchanges as indicated. H atoms and methanol molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The dc magnetic measurements were carried out on a polycrystalline sample in the range of 1.8−300 K at an external field of 1000 G. For magnetization measurements, the sample was restrained in eicosane to prevent torquing. The χM T curve, with a ferromagnetic main pattern and an antiferromagnetic trend at lower T, is shown in Figure . At low temperatures, 1 exhibits peculiar magnetic properties. As shown in Figure S4 in the Supporting Information, χM reaches a maximum at 4.8 K for low fields, which broadens as H increases and disappears for H > 3500 G, proving a field-induced transition from an antiferromagnetic to a ferromagnetic ground state. ac susceptibility measurements at different frequencies (500, 1000, and 1400 Hz) in a zero dc field show a zero out-of-phase component (χ‘ ‘) and the in-phase one (χ‘) practically coincident to the χM curve. No frequency-dependent behavior was observed. The transition temperature (T N) can be estimated as 4.4 K by the maximum of d(χ‘T)/dT at 1000 Hz. The field dependence of the magnetization up to 50 kG was measured at various temperatures (1.8, 2.8, 3.8, and 5.0 K; Figure ). As the temperature is reduced, the isotherms become increasing sigmoidal. The value of the critical field (H C) is 3600 G (the inflection point in the inset of Figure ). The curve at 1.8 K has the behavior expected for a metamagnet with a large anisotropy. Up to 50 kG, the maximum recorded magnetization, ∼3 NμB, is not reached, yet the saturation value, g Mn S Mn+ g Fe S Fe ∼ 5 NμB, shows, however, a firmly increasing slope.
elements.clean_text: The dc magnetic measurements were carried out on a polycrystalline sample in the range of 1.8-300 K at an external field of 1000 G. For magnetization measurements, the sample was restrained in eicosane to prevent torquing. The χM T curve, with a ferromagnetic main pattern and an antiferromagnetic trend at lower T, is shown in Figure . At low temperatures, 1 exhibits peculiar magnetic properties. As shown in Figure S4 in the Supporting Information, χM reaches a maximum at 4.8 K for low fields, which broadens as H increases and disappears for H > 3500 G, proving a field-induced transition from an antiferromagnetic to a ferromagnetic ground state. ac susceptibility measurements at different frequencies (500, 1000, and 1400 Hz) in a zero dc field show a zero out-of-phase component (χ‘‘) and the in-phase one (χ‘) practically coincident to the χM curve. No frequency-dependent behavior was observed. The transition temperature (T N) can be estimated as 4.4 K by the maximum of d(χ‘T)/dT at 1000 Hz. The field dependence of the magnetization up to 50 kG was measured at various temperatures (1.8, 2.8, 3.8, and 5.0 K; Figure ). As the temperature is reduced, the isotherms become increasing sigmoidal. The value of the critical field (H C) is 3600 G (the inflection point in the inset of Figure ). The curve at 1.8 K has the behavior expected for a metamagnet with a large anisotropy. Up to 50 kG, the maximum recorded magnetization, ~3 NμB, is not reached, yet the saturation value, g Mn S Mn+ g Fe S Fe ~ 5 NμB, shows, however, a firmly increasing slope.

elements.content: χM T vs T for 1. Solids lines:  fit with different interchain models. Inset:  dependence of relative magnetization M vs H and T computed using the Ising-like interchain interaction model, parallel with the experimental pattern (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The alternating topology is described with J a and J b Mn(III)−Fe(III) coupling parameters (Figure ). The anisotropy of Mn(III) is accounted for by the D axial ZFS term. Under periodicity conditions, the infinite chain is equivalent to a ring. The finite alternating {MnFe} n rings can be cut in two ways, through J a or J b contacts. At sufficiently large n, the magnetism of the ring and open chains converge identically. Taking an average of χM T computed for the ring and the two chains, one achieves a smooth trend to the simulation of the infinite chain. We afforded the fit for the n = 3 case, with larger systems being prohibitive in iterative procedures (the number of spin states is 10 n ). A mean-field parameter (zJ < 0) was tentatively considered to explain the decrease of χM T in the 1.8−4 K range. However, the fit with g = 2.11, J a = 1.93 cm-1, J b = 1.83 cm-1, zJ = −0.19 cm-1, and D = −2.41 cm-1 does not show a good curve match. Thorough improvement attempts revealed the intrinsic incapacity of the mean field to account well for the case. The mean field works with a −zJ· 〈 〉 Hamiltonian defined as an Ising-like term between spin projections of each i state and the averaged spin projection. It does not introduce new states, amending only the free system ones. For two interacting chains, with N states each, the full Heisenberg or Ising coupling would produce N  2 levels, prohibitively multiplying the number of states, beyond the necessary phenomenology of the weak interaction. The compromise between standard mean-field and regular interchain Ising models is reached by conceiving Ising-like terms acting only between degenerate states of the two chains. Then, instead of N  2 states, we introduce 2N ones for the resonant interaction of chain levels, ascribed by the −zJ· (1) (2) term, with (1) and (2) labeling the chains. The coupling parameter in the new Hamiltonian is conventionally kept in the zJ notation. It is intuitive that the resonant effects between degenerate levels play a higher effective role than the (1) (2) cross terms.
elements.clean_text: The alternating topology is described with J a and J b Mn(III)-Fe(III) coupling parameters (Figure ). The anisotropy of Mn(III) is accounted for by the D axial ZFS term. Under periodicity conditions, the infinite chain is equivalent to a ring. The finite alternating {MnFe} n  rings can be cut in two ways, through J a or J b contacts. At sufficiently large n, the magnetism of the ring and open chains converge identically. Taking an average of χM T computed for the ring and the two chains, one achieves a smooth trend to the simulation of the infinite chain. We afforded the fit for the n = 3 case, with larger systems being prohibitive in iterative procedures (the number of spin states is 10 n  ). A mean-field parameter (zJ < 0) was tentatively considered to explain the decrease of χM T in the 1.8-4 K range. However, the fit with g = 2.11, J a = 1.93 cm-1, J b = 1.83 cm-1, zJ = -0.19 cm-1, and D = -2.41 cm-1 does not show a good curve match. Thorough improvement attempts revealed the intrinsic incapacity of the mean field to account well for the case. The mean field works with a -zJ⋅   〈   〉 Hamiltonian  defined as an Ising-like term between spin projections of each i state and the averaged spin projection. It does not introduce new states, amending only the free system ones. For two interacting chains, with N states each, the full Heisenberg or Ising coupling would produce N 2 levels, prohibitively multiplying the number of states, beyond the necessary phenomenology of the weak interaction. The compromise between standard mean-field and regular interchain Ising models is reached by conceiving Ising-like terms acting only between degenerate states of the two chains. Then, instead of N 2 states, we introduce 2N ones for the resonant interaction of chain levels, ascribed by the -zJ⋅   (1)   (2) term, with (1) and (2) labeling the chains. The coupling parameter in the new Hamiltonian is conventionally kept in the zJ notation. It is intuitive that the resonant effects between degenerate levels play a higher effective role than the   (1)   (2) cross terms.

elements.content: With this model, χM T can be fitted in an excellent manner, giving g = 2.11, J a = 1.66 cm-1, J b = 1.21 cm-1, zJ = −0.038 cm-1, and D = −0.95 cm-1. D is in the usual range (−1 to −4 cm-1) for Schiff base complexes. The considered model also reproduces the patterns of M vs H and T in a semiquantitative manner (the upper insets in Figures and ). Possibly, the χM T fit is nonunique, on the basis of compensation effects usual in multiparametric cases. A multibranch fit of χM T and M to the experimental data is taken as the goal of a further work. Confined to the actual form, the model enables the understanding of the lattice magnetism in 1. The steep decrease in χM T at low temperature is due to the interchain antiferromagnetic coupling. The interchain Ising-like resonant interaction model, which tacitly incorporates the chain anisotropy, explains the observed magnetization effects. Taking two chains for the effective modeling of the supramolecular coupling, we have for each state i of the individual chain a 2|zJ|( )2 gap between four collective states grouped in two degenerate pairs, one set originating from the {(+ , + ), (− , − )} chain couples and another set from the {(+ , − ), (− , + )} ones. The field-tuned crossing of the ground-state levels (with the above degeneracy pattern) determines the recorded phase transition (Scheme S4 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: With this model, χM T can be fitted in an excellent manner, giving g = 2.11, J a = 1.66 cm-1, J b = 1.21 cm-1, zJ = -0.038 cm-1, and D = -0.95 cm-1. D is in the usual range (-1 to -4 cm-1) for Schiff base complexes. The considered model also reproduces the patterns of M vs H and T in a semiquantitative manner (the upper insets in Figures  and ). Possibly, the χM T fit is nonunique, on the basis of compensation effects usual in multiparametric cases. A multibranch fit of χM T and M to the experimental data is taken as the goal of a further work. Confined to the actual form, the model enables the understanding of the lattice magnetism in 1. The steep decrease in χM T at low temperature is due to the interchain antiferromagnetic coupling. The interchain Ising-like resonant interaction model, which tacitly incorporates the chain anisotropy, explains the observed magnetization effects. Taking two chains for the effective modeling of the supramolecular coupling, we have for each state i of the individual chain a 2|zJ|(   )2 gap between four collective states grouped in two degenerate pairs, one set originating from the {(+   , +   ), (-   , -   )} chain couples and another set from the {(+   , -   ), (-   , +   )} ones. The field-tuned crossing of the ground-state levels (with the above degeneracy pattern) determines the recorded phase transition (Scheme S4 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The ab initio calculations were taken as a complement in the magnetostructural analysis. The broken-symmetry density functional theory (DFT) calculations performed on corresponding a and b {FeMn} dimer moieties taken from the experimental geometry lead to J a = 2.4 cm-1 and J b = 1.7 cm-1 estimations, which are consistent with the range and sign of the experimental fit values.
elements.clean_text: The ab initio calculations were taken as a complement in the magnetostructural analysis. The broken-symmetry density functional theory (DFT) calculations performed on corresponding a and b {FeMn} dimer moieties taken from the experimental geometry lead to J a = 2.4 cm-1 and J b = 1.7 cm-1 estimations, which are consistent with the range and sign of the experimental fit values.

elements.content: The spin populations along the cyanide bridge show the following patterns:  Mn4αNδαCδ‘βFe1α for the broken-symmetry high-spin (BHS) case and Mn4αNδαCδ‘αFe1β for the broken-symmetry low-spin (BLS) case (Figure and spin populations in the Supporting Information). A spin-polarization effect takes place at the Fe−C contact, which can be presented as a cause of ferromagnetism. The ferromagnetic interaction can also be understood by observing that the magnetic orbital on Fe(III) has a dπ nature (from t2g parentage) that falls into an orthongonality relationship with the σ (d z 2 ) type magnetic orbital oriented along the CN−Mn−NC mean axes. Because of the Mn(III) d z 2 type molecular orbital's relative interaction propensity toward the Fe(III) center, this ferromagnetic channel dominates the overall coupling.
elements.clean_text: The spin populations along the cyanide bridge show the following patterns: Mn4αNδαCδ‘βFe1α for the broken-symmetry high-spin (BHS) case and Mn4αNδαCδ‘αFe1β for the broken-symmetry low-spin (BLS) case (Figure  and spin populations in the Supporting Information). A spin-polarization effect takes place at the Fe-C contact, which can be presented as a cause of ferromagnetism. The ferromagnetic interaction can also be understood by observing that the magnetic orbital on Fe(III) has a dπ nature (from t2g parentage) that falls into an orthongonality relationship with the σ (d z   2 ) type magnetic orbital oriented along the CN-Mn-NC mean axes. Because of the Mn(III) d z   2  type molecular orbital's relative interaction propensity toward the Fe(III) center, this ferromagnetic channel dominates the overall coupling.

elements.content: Spin-density maps from broken-symmetry DFT calculations for the a dimer sequence (α in blue; β in light yellow). The solid surfaces correspond to 0.05 e Å-3 and the transparent ones to 0.002 e Å-3 isovalues.
elements.clean_text: 4  Spin-density maps from broken-symmetry DFT calculations for the a dimer sequence (α in blue; β in light yellow). The solid surfaces correspond to 0.05 e Å-3 and the transparent ones to 0.002 e Å-3 isovalues.

elements.content: In summary, we firmly conclude the ferromagnetic nature of the two Fe(III)−Mn(III) couplings, with certain differentiation due to the differences in bridging angles. The antiferromagnetic interchain coupling causes the metamagnetic behavior of 1 with loss of magnetization relaxation effects. Further synthetic and interpretation works on related systems are underway.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we firmly conclude the ferromagnetic nature of the two Fe(III)-Mn(III) couplings, with certain differentiation due to the differences in bridging angles. The antiferromagnetic interchain coupling causes the metamagnetic behavior of 1 with loss of magnetization relaxation effects. Further synthetic and interpretation works on related systems are underway.

metadata.title:
Cyanide-Bridged Fe(III)−Mn(III) Chain with Metamagnetic Properties and
Significant Magnetic Anisotropy
